page.title: 09The Frimley Fuel Allotments
page.content: The Fuel Allotments form a stretch of woodland joining heathland, owned by the army, called the Ranges. From Elizabethan times the poor people of the district were allowed to go there and gather wood for fuel, hence the name. The trees are generally conifers, although there are quite a number of Silver Birch, Oak, and Goat Willow. The ground is mainly sandy with stony black soil, many small streams and marshes covered with algae. There are many different insects: two species of ladybird (the seven spotted and an orange spotted) and black beetles. But the most common insects are the wood ants. One ant hill, stretching from 70cm above ground level to 1m below, can contain more ants than the world's biggest city contains people.
